div.p: >> Hi, this is Joyce Farrell.

This is an introduction to
object-oriented programming.

The features of object-oriented
programming languages include
several that are not included

in procedural programming
languages.

For example, object-oriented
programs have classes.

Classes are categories
of objects.
They also have objects.

Objects are instances
of classes.

Classes are similar to
a blueprint or a recipe.

It describes what
an object will be

like when one is
actually created.

An object is more like an actual
house or an actual cookie,

something that is
already created

from the blueprint
or the recipe.

Object-oriented programming
languages also
support encapsulation.

That means that the data
and methods that pertain

to an object are stored
as a single entity.
Inheritance is another feature

of object-oriented
programming languages.

Inheritance gives
you the ability

to extend existing
classes and make new ones
that are based on the originals.

Object-oriented programming
languages also
support polymorphism.
This is the ability of a method

to act correctly even though
it uses different object types.
Let's take a look at a class.

Suppose you decide to start a
business that produces videos

and you decide that
the attributes

of a video will include a
title and a running time.

You also decide methods you'll
need include methods to create,
distribute and play the videos.
This is a class description.

When you actually create an
object, it will have a title

and a running time and it
will have access to all
of the methods in its class.

You then can create
a different object

that perhaps has
a different title

or a different running
time and so on.

You can create any
number of objects
from the original blueprint.

Encapsulation is the feature of
combining all of the attributes

and methods into
a single package.

When you create an object from
a class, it contains everything
that belongs to the class.

Therefore, when you write a
method, such as one like this

that accepts a video
as a parameter,

you can pass the
object in as a group.

You don't have to send
the title, running time

or other attributes separately
and the method has access

to everything that
the class has.
Inheritance is the ability

to create a class
from an existing one.

Suppose you decide you're going
to produce educational videos

and you decide that their
attributes should be a title,
a running time and a grade level

and that their methods
should include create,
distribute and play.

Well you've already created
most of this with a video.

The only new thing here
is the grade level.

Everything else already
exists in another class.

So instead of creating
the educational video

from the start, you
can inherit from video.

When you create the educational
video class, all you have

to do is add one new
attribute, grade level,

and take everything else
from the existing class.

When you create an object
that is an educational video,

it not only has a grade
level, it also has a title

and a running time and access
to all the video methods.

If you create another
educational video object,

same thing, it could have
the same or different title,

same or different
running time and same
or different grade level.

Polymorphism gives you the
ability to write a single method

that works appropriately with
different kinds of objects.

For example, suppose you
create a video object.

Then suppose you also create
an educational video object.

A method that accepts a
video object knows how

to work appropriately
if you send it a video.

It knows how to distribute
a video, for example.

And it also knows how
to work appropriately

if you send it an
educational video.
It knows how to distribute that.

Polymorphism allows you to
write one method that can work
with multiple types of objects.

Again, the features of object-
oriented programs include

classes and objects,
encapsulation,
inheritance and polymorphism.

That's a brief introduction to
object-oriented programming.
Thanks for watching.
